title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be repeated under this section or section 1012. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority by transmitting a special message to Congress. The special message must specify the budget authority to be rescinded and follow certain procedures for expedited consideration in Congress. On the third day after receiving a special message, any Member of the House may introduce a bill or joint resolution. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days without substantive revision. If the committee fails to do so, it will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar. A bill or joint resolution must be voted on within 10 days of introduction in the House. If passed, it is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House on the same day. A bill or joint resolution transmitted to the House of Representatives or the Senate must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations of that House. The committee must report the bill without substantive revision within seven days of receiving it. Failure to do so results in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill is placed on the appropriate calendar for a vote on final passage. The House of Representatives or Senate must refer a bill or joint resolution to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days. If not, the bill is automatically discharged and placed on the calendar for a vote. The House must take action on the bill within 10 days of continuous session, with a motion to proceed being highly privileged and not debatable. Amendments to the motion are not allowed. Debate on a bill or joint resolution in the House of Representatives is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Further debate limitations are not allowed, and motions to recommit or reconsider the vote are also not permitted. Appeals on procedural decisions related to the bill are allowed. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section in the Senate is governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives. A motion to proceed to the consideration of a bill or joint resolution is privileged and not debatable, with a 10-hour limit on debate and related motions. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be limited to not more than 1 hour, equally divided between the mover and the manager of the bill or joint resolution, with additional time allotted by the leaders if needed. The Senate limits debate time on debatable motions or appeals for bills or joint resolutions under this section. Amendments are prohibited, and any budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation. The Senate limits debate time on motions or appeals for bills. Amendments are prohibited, and budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation the day after a bill is defeated in Congress. Definitions for terms like 'appropriation Act' and 'continuity of a session of Congress' are provided. The text discusses the transmission of special messages during Congress sessions and amendments to Section 904 of the Act.
